title: Are people who are 'old school' looked down in society? - Quora

response.answer_text: No. There will always be an audience and appreciation and lure of “old school”…there always has been…in the 69s, the hippies discovered their heroes, Hendrix , Clapton and Beck, worshipped the old black blues artists, who’d fallen on hard time. The white audience gave them their best years until the end of their lives. Classic Rock is always making a comeback…because it’s Classic…not because we were smarter , cooler(maybe) of “better” (maybe)…if we were it was because it was new, the times were more positive and music was THE THING…now it’s video games and I-Phones…seems like little kid stuff compared to music, which is not a big thing to most people now. Fashion, the old styles always come back, Young people are buying vinyl records! I was the LAST GUY to stop buying them, I think…I ain’t goin’ back. People LOVE to say they recorded on reel to reel tape and recordig gear from the 50s. You can have it…I’m not a museum curator, I want to make as much music as possible..for no logical reason, I’m just driven…it give s me purpose. I just made friends with a young (to my 68) black guy who’s an electrican working at my house. We talked music and I’m collaborating with him. He gave me some modern hip hop stuff of his to play bass on and I gave him a classic rock bass/drum track to work on. I never cared if I was looked down on by “society”…in fact, I didn’t WANT to belong to the “Fraternity of Man” or any of the woke fraternities. I want to stand by myself. Old school, new school, just “the good stuff”, by MY standards. I’m NOT a victim because I did it on purpose, but I always maintained a look that would make people react, make me “not belong”…except to my society. Music is my only perspective for yuor question, but it kind of incorporates a lot of other things.

The ‘old school’ is any group of people who are traditionalists: they do things the way like it used to be done in the past, because they believe the older ways are better (not likely more efficient). ‘Old school’ means something close to old-fashioned, but I like to think of it as more traditional - a term with a hint of pride. By the way, old-fashioned usually has a negative connoction attached to it. However, being old-fashioned is nothing to be ashamed of, especially when you add a bit of modern element to it. Be the kind of ‘old school’ who differentiates the good and bad from the past and present, and takes only the best of the past and improvises it to fit into present modern-day standards. In other words, you keep certain things worth keeping alive while letting go of those that should have never existed in the first place. If you could practice the above, who is going to look down on you ‘old school’?

It truly depends on which part of society is doing the looking. A lot depends upon whether one is part of a group that always needs to be ““forward-looking” and thinks the past should basically be ““re-imagined” to fit some more postmodern narrative ( you know, the people that think ““Hey Boomer” is some ultimate put-down) or if one values tradition and history in the classical sense. I do think that many younger people tend to reject what they see as “old”, whether it is mores and attitudes that have outlived their time or elderly people who (in their opinion) have outlived their usefulness. Sometimes ““old school” just means an older and more complex way of building something or tackling a problem. Some would put aside traditional craftsmanship or artistry for more efficiency and lower cost. Some people think ““old school” punishment ( like spanking children) is outdated and cruel. Some people think society would be better if we put some old-fashioned discipline back in place and burned the Child Psychology books. In general, I think ““old school” implies a toughness, physicality, ingenuity and individualism that is counter to postmodern Progressivism. Personally, I think old school is badass— but I’m old. LOL.

Ha, I’m old-school. Most of the people I know are old school. We are respected because we have expertise on our side, and we spent decades perfecting all those skills for which young people have only better or faster methods. 360-degree expertise is on our side, and being faster does not mean being better. Now young people don’t ever want to admit this. They call us “old” and “obsolete” and “old-school.” Until they get stuck because their new faster method never took into account all the ways their endeavors could go wrong. And how could those youngsters know if they have no experience let alone expertise? If young people want to take this route, we old-school folks can handle the name-calling. We already know that with expertise comes relentless patience. We know something even more important: We were once the ones with those better, faster methods of doing things, and we learned along the way (sometimes the hard way) that those old-school folks had all of the problem-solving expertise—and the patience. While we only had technology and speed. Our old-school mentors taught us how to solve problems, same as they taught us how to walk and talk. So we’ll continue to humor and encourage the youngsters to keep plugging away at their newer, faster methods. We know they’ll inevitably come to us voluntarily and ask for help. ;)

I’m definitely what would be described as “Old School” yet I don’t look down on society. For the most part the world has improved drastically during my life. I’m over 70 and I think in my life there have been more improvements in every aspect of life than in any other time in history. That said, I think there is one area we have perhaps taken a step or two backwards. In the area of relationships we now describe total strangers as “friends” and people we have never met a BFF’s. We meet online, fall in love online, get ghosted online, breakup online. When we finally meet the digital love of our life we are often disappointed due to exaggerations made online. If I could change anything it would be people spending more time generating true, well rounded relationships that lead to well rounded romances and well rounded marriages with well adjusted children that also value the concept of developing solid relationships face to face.

i don’t think so. if you mean old school like someone who likes music from decades ago, has a penchant for sports cars and westerns or however you may define it. maybe my idea of old school is preferring anything that isn’t always about “today”. i consider myself old school and i don’t use instagram or twitter as much as the average person and despite that, i believe in my heart i’m worthy of the full respect of someone half my age because my values are old school but goodies. treat people with dignity, faith, confidence and it doesn’t matter if you’re old school. btw, i was good friends with a man almost 40 years older than me because he had a sense of humor and i admired the fact he lived a life that had a lot to teach me and anyone who’s many generations younger than i am. never discount someone older than you as they just might have lots to teach.

Sort of. There is always the suspicion that “Old School” is just one step from being completely out of date. Which is another way of saying “Old Fashioned”. We tend to like things that are new, trendy and flashy. Things that are hip and cool. But when they get too hip and too cool, well that’s when they become fads. And that’s when they become yesterday’s news. Its at that point, when we decide that we need to get back to basics. Whether it's in the arts, or in music or even in engineering or architecture. That’s when we get back to our roots. We go Old School.

Yes. They seem not in with the latest fad and music.  They seem like the fools of society. Funny, the true geniuses are the ones who hardly keep up with the latest fad but latest news. While others know what’s the latest song by John Meyer, others know who is the newest president of a certain country around the world.  The latest fad doesn’t add value to your life as much as the latest news. Would you believe some people do not know who Nelson Mandela is?  But they know the latest make of shoes.

Probably each generation does it to some extent. When we are younger we go through the ‘eye roll’ stage where we think we know more than our elders. But guess what? With the advent of internet and all this technology, kids really do know more than a lot of us older folks when it comes to that area. But don’t let the ‘old school’ folks fool anyone. They are far from dumb. They hold a lot of wisdom in different areas and have gone through the lessons of life and are seasoned. It would be advantageous to listen to their wisdom and add it to your own. And visa versa.

That depends on if you can understand what old school means to you. old school can be applied to any time in history. However, I understand your question. Hopefully the youth of any generation can understand and admire what most people understand as old school.

No, It comes from the” Old Schools “ in Great Britain and America that had a great deal of prestige and strong reputations for standing out academically, and their students becoming leaders in the modern world, It also has a connotation of doing things the old fashioned way, but in the best sense, traditionally, but carefully.
I don’t think so, I think that adults running around saying “legit” when at work and “low key” need help. Everyone has their place in this world and someone has to be old school.
